Description.val:
The FY 2021 funding request was reduced by $10 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.

[P40A / DC004 CALIBRATION STANDARDS]: These funds procure Calibration Standards to execute a detailed, multi-year sustainment and modernization plan for intermediate, organizational and depot level maintenance activities. Calibration Standards are equipment employed to ensure the accuracy of test equipment used to install, align, and maintain all navy weapons systems ashore and afloat. The Navy's inventory of Calibration Standards are approaching obsolescence and require modernization to avoid deterioration in accuracy and calibration of our weapons systems. Many of the original standards are no longer in production, so replacement standards must be purchased from newer model inventory, some of which have a greater unit cost. Failure to maintain accurate calibration standards will cause our weapons systems to perform below expectations. The impacts would range from premature mechanical failures due to incorrectly installed mechanical components, to radar and missile operational inaccuracies due to improperly set components. A defined, multi-year modernization plan for Calibration Standards is in place. The unit cost of the replacement calibration standards to be procured, range from $11K (general purpose power meter) to $350K (vector network analyzer); whereas the unit cost of older standards procured in prior years ranged from $18K to $52K. This change in unit cost is attributable to the diversity and varying complexity of calibration standards to be procured and their measurement requirements. Several multi-year contracts requirements have been initiated and several more packages are in process.  Any reduction or delay in funding for Calibration Standards will result in a negative impact to the Fleet and default Navy contract awards.  Not modernizing/procuring the planned calibration standards due to insufficient (reduced) funding will drastically impact the overall health of the Navy calibration program, directly impacting the performance of every NAVSEA cognizance weapon system including the Aegis Weapon System afloat and Aegis Ashore Romania/Poland, AN/APX-72 IFF transponder, AN/BRD-7 ECM Intercept System, AN/SQQ-34 ASW Module and all afloat radio systems. Furthermore, a reduction degrades readiness to support ships and availabilities within all major naval shipyards. Calibration Standards modernization, procurement and outfitting is a readiness enabler and therefore this reduction would cause a major break in the fleet readiness kill chain.

[P40A / DC019 RADAR RESTORATION AN/SPS-67 ANTENNA]: Funding in this line establishes an antenna manufacturing capability at Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC) Crane needed to provide additional rotatable pool antennas and associated engineering changes for the AN/SPS-67(V)3 to support the restoration of installed fleet antennas. The current number of available antennas is insufficient to support the fleet population. This has led to antennas operating in the field beyond their periodicity, resulting in decreased detection and tracking capability.

[P40A / DC020 DUAL BAND RADAR (DBR)]: Funding is required to establish the In-Service Engineering Agent (ISEA), Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) production services and support for Configuration Management. Funding also implements the DBR Life Cycle Sustainment Plan (LCSP) and infrastructure, Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) Plan, associated hardware and software obsolescence mod kits, procurement of Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), associated logistics products and on-board allowance requirements to enable system operation. Production Support is also required to assist with DBR Combat System Integration and Technical Documentation. Funding also supports CVN 78 and DDG 1000 Class Combat System Ship Qualification Testing (CSSQT). Additional limitations will be identified during CVN78/DDG1000 Shipboard Activation, Integration and At-Sea Testing. Additionally, as a result of DBR land based and Self Defense Test Ship (SDTS) events limitations were identified in the Dual Band Radar (DBR) performance that directly impacted CVN 78 and DDG 1000 class readiness. These limitations require ECPs to correct the performance areas of the radar for Air Traffic Control and Integrated Combat Systems (e.g., False Clutter Tracks, Short Range Tracking, General Tracking, Slow Air Tracking, Waveform Scheduling, and code stability). The Prime Contractor and Government Technical Team have documented critical radar issues that require correction via ECPs.  Funding for these ECP efforts is required due to the engineering and technical complexity of the change proposals needed to satisfy combat system qualification requirements. The Under Secretary of Defense (Acquisition, Technology and Logistics) Independent Review Team (IRT) recommended that the Navy establish infrastructure and mechanisms to accelerate the acquisition of spares for DBR and develop a repair capability for DBR equipment. DBR Special Test Equipment and Infrastructure funding for (1) test equipment and support for a repair depot for assemblies and subassemblies for DBR components, including Common Array Power System (CAPS), and Common Array Cooling System (CACS); (2) resolution of system obsolescence that will degrade system Ao; and, (3) establishment of product support engineering infrastructure. The additional DBR sustainment and infrastructure efforts will facilitate the transition of material sparing support of DBR to NAVSUP.

[P40A / DC021 AN/SPS-67(V)5 MARITIME RADAR PROCESSOR (MRP)]: The Maritime Radar Processor (MRP) was developed to improve the detection of small boats/targets by USN ships. Funding in this line will be used to integrate and field small boat detection software improvements to AN/SPS-67(V)5 Surface Search Radar. Funding will also be used to field software build 3.0 for various corrections including tracker fixes, Windows Operating System (OS) elimination, improved Information Assurance (IA) posture, and squint correction to improve bearing accuracy.

[P40A / DC012 AN/SPS-74(V) PERISCOPE DETECTION RADAR]: AN/SPS-74(V) PERISCOPE DETECTION RADAR (PDR): The CVN Periscope Detection Radar (PDR), AN/SPS-74(V) is a radar that provides automatic detection and discrimination of submarine periscopes using advanced algorithms enabling discrimination of periscopes from surface contacts, buoys, small boats, floating mines, etc. Four Advanced Development Models(ADMs) have been installed and are operating on CVN class ships. The AN/SPS-74 program was cancelled in FY12. FY19 will be used for Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) to address obsolescence issues, sustainment, and continued operation of installed AN/SPS-74 ADMs as well as de-installation. Funding for SPS-74 ended in FY19.

[P40A / DC022 RADAR RESTORATION MATERIAL]: Radar Restoration funding procures components to support radar restoration (Arrays and miscellaneous Antenna Sub-Assemblies) and Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) to address obsolescence and improve supportability. The Antenna Overhaul Kits line has been added to the budget starting in FY20 due to the revised bill of materials and overhaul procedures associated with Radar Restoration assets. The Antenna Overhaul Kit consists of various components including waveguides, nuts, bolts, bearings, washers, seals, etc. In order to fund the new Antenna Overhaul requirement, the quantity of SPS-48 Arrays has been decreased for FY20-FY25.

[P3A / DC001 - SPS-73 RADAR]: The AN/SPS-73(V) Radar provides navigation and general surface search radar functionality on all U.S. Navy ships.  The AN/SPS-73(V)12 is the Automatic Radar Plotting Aid (ARPA).
Navigation Radar for the U.S. Navy Funding will be utilized for engineering changes, which will improve surface combatant's ability to engage fast attack craft/fast in shore attack craft (FAC/FIAC) tracking and periscope detection and discrimination, as well as address cybersecurity shortfalls and Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) obsolescence of the legacy AN/SPS-73 systems.   The AN/SPS-73 Next Generation Surface Search Radar (NGSSR) will update the current AN/SPS-73(V)12 and replace the AN/SPS-67(V) and all commercially provided Navigation Radars fielded in the fleet.  NGSSR production has been accelerated as a result of the October 2017 Commander Fleet Forces Comprehensive Review, which was directly related to the McCain and Fitzgerald collisions.

[P3A - 2 / DC009 - AN/SPS-48G RADAR OBSOLESCENCE AND AVAILABILITY RECOVERY (ROAR)]: The AN/SPS-48G 3-D Air Surveillance Radar is a follow-on to the existing AN/SPS-48E onboard Aircraft Carriers and large-deck Amphibious ships.  AN/SPS-48G was initiated in response to Fleet complaints regarding AN/SPS-48E reliability and supportability.  Upgrade of the AN/SPS-48E with the AN/SPS-48G remains a high Fleet priority as it will reduce Operation and Support (O&S) costs and improve Operational Availability.  Both factors are cited by the Fleet as unsatisfactory for the AN/SPS-48E. The goal is to replace the AN/SPS-48E as rapidly as possible so the Fleet can realize this cost avoidance. Current efforts include the manufacturing of the AN/SPS-48G upgrade kits with associated production support as well as modifications to the AN/SPS-48G brought about by initial Fleet introduction and Fleet operations. Production lead time is 24 months for the initial unit with subsequent units delivered at two month intervals after initial delivery. Equipment delivery for installation is required thirty days prior to FMP availability start in accordance with Navy Modernization Process Management. Engineering Change Order funding is required to address Fleet recommended modifications/requirements and Information Assurance, Obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Sources (DMS) issues. Engineering Change Proposal funding is required to initiate incorporation of High Diver Detection and Tracking functionality. This capability was designed and incorporated into the AN/SPS-48E after design of the AN/SPS-48G had been initiated. This change needs to be translated into the different hardware and software architectures of the AN/SPS-48G. FY18 was the last year of AN/SPS-48G procurements.

[P3A - 3 / DC015 - TACTICAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROCESSOR (TEP)]: Provides real-time volunumeric wind profiles, convective weather detection/display, and radar refractivity assessments from AN/SPY-1 radar returns.  TEP is an adjunct processor and display, tapping radar data from weather and refractivity data, with users able to access information through Secret Internet Protocol Router (SIPR). Funding for TEP ends in FY19. FY19 funding is being used to remove equipment and closeout program.

[P3A - 4 / DC018 - AN/SPY-1 RM&A IMPROVEMENTS]: DC018 AN/SPY-1 RM&A IMPROVEMENTS - These Reliability, Maintainability, and Availability (RM&A) improvements are intended to reduce cascading failures, mitigate obsolescence issues, and improve reliability in support of Anti-Air Warfare (AAW) and Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) missions while still providing AN/SPY-1 Radar Total Ownership Cost (TOC) reductions. The improvements include, but are not limited to, installation for Sidewall Capacitor Circuit Protection and 10kW Traveling Wave Tube (TWT) Monitoring Circuits Ordnance Alterations (ORDALTS) for AN/SPY-1; B (V), D, D (V), CG and DDGs. Solid State Switch Assemblies (SSSA) will replace legacy switch tube modulator deck via an ORDALT.  Multi-Mission Signal Processor (MMSP) is the signal processor for the AN/SPY-1 radar.  MMSP Refresh (MMSP-R) cabinets will be procured to provide production representative configurations for land-based testing and training to support AEGIS ships at AEGIS Training and Readiness Center (ATRC) and Surface Combat System Center (SCSC) Wallops Island. Procurement and installation of SSSA for DDG Ships, Shore Sites and Spares are aligned with the DDG Modernization availability periods.

[P3A - 5 / DC024 - AMDR Operations and Support (O&S)]: DC024 AMDR Operations and Support (O&S) - AMDR has been designated the AN/SPY-6(V)1 to address Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) and Air Defense (AD) capability gaps identified in the Maritime Air and Missile Defense of Joint Forces (MAMDJF) Initial Capabilities Document (ICD); AN/SPY-6(V)1 will be initially fielded on the DDG-51 FLT-III platform. A variant of the AN/SPY-6(V) will replace the AN/SPY-1 radar on existing DDG 51 FLT-IIA ships. The AN/SPY-6(V) Product Support Strategy established NSWC Port Hueneme Division as the Product Support Integrator (PSI) for overall system Operational Availability (AO) and Backend Processing (BEP) subsystem(s) Life Cycle Support. The BEP is comprised of Commercial off the Shelf (COTS) x86 based Modular Open System Architecture (MOSA), allowing for Form-Fit-Function (FFF) replacement with next generation server and processer technology. A Product Support Provider (PSP), defined in the LCSP and Acquisition Strategy, as the Advanced Processing System (APS) contract vendor will execute Supply Support of the BEP. The APS PSP contributes to overall system readiness by managing BEP repair/replacement, obsolescence, and technology refresh by attrition within a performance based service contract, leveraging AN/SPY-6(V)'s MOSA and COTS x86 industrial base. Funding will sustain the Navy's next generation family of radars, AN/SPY-6(V). This applies to all current and future variants of the AN/SPY-6(V); including future modifications or separate programs to address different mission areas and utilization onboard different ship classes. 

The "To Complete" is represented of the AN/SPY-6(V)1's full 40 year life cycle across 22 ship years (880 ship years).

[P3A - 6 / DC025 - SPEIR BLOCK I]: SPEIR Block I will provide a common EO/IR Electronic Support (ES) capability to all surface ships that will passively find, fix, track, and target current / emerging threats in support of the following warfare missions: Navigation, Counter Fast Attack Craft (FAC) / Fast In-shore Attack Craft (FIAC), Counter Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) / Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV), and Anti-Ship Cruise Missile (ASCM) Defense. SPEIR Block I will consist of a passive Wide Field of View (WFOV) capability with a 360 degree field-of-view optical sensor for panoramic detection, tracking, and identification for 24/7 day/night shipboard situational awareness.  SPEIR Block I will also include an enhanced, high resolution Narrow Field of View (NFOV)  and laser system capability that will provide range-finding and precision 3D target tracking. SPEIR Block II will be a future program that will build on Block I and add capability for Periscope Detection and Discrimination (PDD) and Mine Like Object (MLO) avoidance. Development Status/Major Milestones are: Milestone B, procurement of Long Lead Material (LLM) and Milestone C Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP).  The acquisition strategy for the FY23 LRIP units is to procure Long Lead Material (LLTM) for one shore site and one Fleet unit, with the completion of the FY23 LRIPs being awarded at MS C planned for 3QFY24.

There will be three configurations for the SPEIR Block I system:  1.1.1 SPEIR Block I provides funding for DDG 51, CG, LCS and LPD class ships and also consists of the WFOV, NFOV and laser capability.  1.1.2 SPEIR Block I Scaled is for CVN, LHD and LHA class ships.  The scaled configuration will provide the WFOV capability and will be integrated with existing NFOV capability on these classes of ships. 1.1.3 is the SPEIR Shore Site configuration. The shore site configuration is a partial configuration specifically to support shore based training and testing.

Name.@footnote: Calibration Standards equipment unit costs and quantities vary due to the diversity and varying complexity of Calibration Standards equipment being procured from year to year; the requested funding addresses calibration and maintenance operational requirements across shipboard/shore-based activities and programs.

Since the FY 2020 President's Budget request, the increase in FY19 DBR Special Test Equipment funding was due to the approval of additional funding to address DBR sustainment issues.  The FY19 funds were focused on the resolution of component obsolescence issues.  The DBR program also invested in the initial infrastructure that supports repairs of components at the DBR Depot Repair facility. The FY19 funding will be used to procure a test station required for VSR component repairs.  DBR program funding initiated sustainment oversight processes that included a Failure Reporting, Analysis and Corrective Action System (FRACAS) and routine installation of OEM computer software maintenance updates.
Name.val: 4.3) DBR SPECIAL TEST EQUIPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE

Name.@footnote: Radar Restoration funding procures components to support radar restoration (Arrays and miscellaneous Antenna Sub-Assemblies) and Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) to address obsolescence and improve supportability. The Antenna Overhaul Kits line has been added to the budget starting in FY20 due to the revised bill of materials and overhaul procedures associated with Radar Restoration assets. The Antenna Overhaul Kit consists of various components including waveguides, nuts, bolts, bearings, washers, seals, etc. In order to fund the new Antenna Overhaul requirement, the quantity of SPS-48 Arrays has been decreased for FY20-FY25.

Antenna Overhaul Kits line has been added to budget for FY20 and out due to the revised bill of materials and overhaul procedures associated with Radar Restoration assets. The Antenna Overhaul Kit consist of various components including waveguides, nuts, bolts, bearings, washers, seals, etc. In order to find the new Antenna Overhaul requirement, the quantity of SPS-48 Arrays has been decreased for FY20-FY25. The SPS-48 Array "To Complete" has increased from quantity 1,080 to 1,738.

Production Support funding is required for production of hardware and hardware components and is composed primarily of Warfare Center Activity support, Software Support Activity (SSA), Integrated Logistics Agent (ILA), Acquisition Engineering Agent (AEA), Technical Design Agent (TDA) and Professional Support Services (PSS).  This funding also includes support for cybersecurity compliance and software certification. Production Support funding increased in FY19-FY23 due to demands of qualification unit production support required, ramp up to full rate production and sustainment training/familiarization of navigation and maintainer functions of the NGSSR.

Miscellaneous ECP support is required to address hardware and software obsolescence/availability issues which requires research and investigation by the ISEA to locate, test, and provide suitable substitutes to maintain Fleet Navigation Readiness and Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS). It is also required for NGSSR integration and testing. Miscellaneous ECP funding will continue to be required for SPS-73 efforts throughout the outyears until sufficient quantities of NGSSR are fielded, reducing the burden of the legacy systems. Miscellaneous ECP funding supports the NGSSR schedule and the SPS-73 legacy systems as required.

Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) funding is required to accelerate updating the aging and obsolete SPS-73 to the Next Generation Surface Search Radar (NGSSR) configuration, which will address Cyber and Electro-magnetic Warfare threats that did not exist at the time of the original SPS-73 design. NRE funds will be utilized for government efforts to finalize NGSSR specifications, including design/cost trade-offs to assess different features that could affect cost/schedule such as dual system installations, track fusion, tactical training, AEGIS and SSDS combat system interfaces, and cybersecurity. FY19 funding for system procurements was decreased to fully fund the qualification units and associated NRE as a completion task. NRE is required through FY20 to mitigate FAC/FIAC and cybersecurity shortfalls, and to capitalize on periscope detection and discrimination capabilities. Funding will also complete software development, finalize NGSSR hardware configuration and conduct combat system integration and testing. Qualification testing includes navigation radar International Maritime Organization (IMO) and Safety Of Life At Sea (SOLAS) compliance, Periscope Detection and Discrimination (PDD) interface, Combat System Interface validation, Surface Search Radar validation, cybersecurity, shock, Electromagnetic interference (EMI) and environmental.
Name.val: 1.1.2) NEXT GENERATION NON RECURRING ENGINEERING - Organic

Name.@footnote: NGSSR production units will be procured as a result of the October 2017 Commander Fleet Forces Comprehensive Review which is a priority requirement that is directly related to the McCain and Fitzgerald collisions. FY19 funding for system procurements was decreased to fully fund the qualification units and associated NRE in FY19 as a completion task. The installation profile was revised to align with the procurement profile. Contract award of the FY19 system procurements was deferred from FY19 to FY20 due to the requirement to procure the qualification units and associated material with FY19 funding vice FY18 funding as initially planned. The FY19 systems will be awarded with the FY20 systems. Since FY 2020 President's Budget request, FY21-FY25 system procurements decreased due to increased estimated per unit procurement cost and installation cost (the FY20 procurements remained at quantity 40 and the cost per system was adjusted to reflect this increase). Associated following year installs were reduced due to funding reductions and requirement for additional qualification unit funding. Installation funding for AP and planning yard DSA is customarily required up to 2 years prior to the year of installation to support individual ship class drawing packages, ship checks and long lead material unique to the installation in order to maintain alignment with ship availability schedules. Total cost for installations shows both current year installation funding for the quantity of installations in addition to AP and planning yard DSA for current year and/or following year installs.
Name.val: 1.1.3) NEXT GENERATION SURFACE SEARCH RADAR - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: Additional shore site installations were added to the fielding plan in FY20 in response to a fleet request to increase the number of training facilities for navigation training as well as increasing the number of combat system integration lab installations for AEGIS and SSDS development.
Name.val: 1.1.4) NEXT GENERATION SURFACE SEARCH RADAR SHORE SITES - NonOrganic
AN/SPS-73 Next Generation Navigation Radar - ULTRA ELECTRONICS OCEAN SYSTEMS, INC.

Navigation Radar for the U.S. Navy Funding will be utilized for engineering changes, which will improve surface combatant's ability to engage fast attack craft/fast in shore attack craft (FAC/FIAC) tracking and periscope detection and discrimination, as well as address cybersecurity shortfalls and Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) obsolescence of the legacy AN/SPS-73 systems.   The AN/SPS-73 Next Generation Surface Search Radar (NGSSR) will update the current AN/SPS-73(V)12 and replace the AN/SPS-67(V) and all commercially provided Navigation Radars fielded in the fleet. ModificationTitle.val: DC009 - AN/SPS-48G RADAR OBSOLESCENCE AND AVAILABILITY RECOVERY (ROAR)

Name.@footnote: Production Support provides for Government oversight of production, Government and Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) support of production related software and hardware problems, and engineering as well as Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) efforts in support of production and fielding.

Title.val: DC009 - AN/SPS-48G RADAR OBSOLESCENCE AND AVAILABILITY RECOVERY (ROAR)

Name.@footnote: Installation funding for Advanced Planning (AP) and Planning Yard Design Services Allocation (DSA) is required up to one year prior to the year of installation. DSA funds are used for Ship Installation Drawings (SIDs), Alteration Installation Team (AIT) contracting fees, and shipchecks. The installation costs are variable per hull across the FYDP, with the difference being primarily the AP and DSA costs which are variable based on a combination of the number of future installations and the result of coast wide bidding resulting in uncertainty in location and cost.

Engineering Change Proposal funding is primarily to incorporate High Diver Detection and Tracking functionality. This capability was designed and incorporated into the AN/SPS-48E after design of the AN/SPS-48G had been initiated. This change now needs to be translated into the different hardware and software architectures of the AN/SPS-48G.

Description.val:
The AN/SPS-48G 3-D Air Surveillance Radar is a follow-on to the existing AN/SPS-48E onboard Aircraft Carriers and large-deck Amphibious ships.  AN/SPS-48G was initiated in response to Fleet complaints regarding AN/SPS-48E reliability and supportability.  Upgrade of the AN/SPS-48E with the AN/SPS-48G remains a high Fleet priority as it will reduce Operation and Support (O&S) costs and improve Operational Availability.  Both factors are cited by the Fleet as unsatisfactory for the AN/SPS-48E. The goal is to replace the AN/SPS-48E as rapidly as possible so the Fleet can realize this cost avoidance. Current efforts include the manufacturing of the AN/SPS-48G upgrade kits with associated production support as well as modifications to the AN/SPS-48G brought about by initial Fleet introduction and Fleet operations. Production lead time is 24 months for the initial unit with subsequent units delivered at two month intervals after initial delivery. Equipment delivery for installation is required thirty days prior to FMP availability start in accordance with Navy Modernization Process Management. Engineering Change Order funding is required to address Fleet recommended modifications/requirements and Information Assurance, Obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Sources (DMS) issues. Engineering Change Proposal funding is required to initiate incorporation of High Diver Detection and Tracking functionality. This capability was designed and incorporated into the AN/SPS-48E after design of the AN/SPS-48G had been initiated. This change needs to be translated into the different hardware and software architectures of the AN/SPS-48G. FY18 was the last year of AN/SPS-48G procurements.

Installation funding for advanced planning (AP) and planning yard design services allocation (DSA) is required up to one year prior to the year of installation.  DSA funds are used for Ship Installation Drawings (SIDs), Alteration Installation Team (AIT) contracting fees, and shipchecks. The FY17 $4M reduction to installation has resulted in movement of LHA 6 to outside the FYDP and LPD 22 to FY21. LPD 20 was moved from FY21 to FY23 and LPD 18 was moved from FY22 to "To Complete" due to ships' schedules.

Name.@footnote: FY20-FY25 funding zero'd due to higher priority requirement for resources. Directed to terminate program and remove DDG equipment. Funding reallocated to execute program closeout and equipment removal.

Description.val: DC018 AN/SPY-1 RM&A IMPROVEMENTS - These Reliability, Maintainability, and Availability (RM&A) improvements are intended to reduce cascading failures, mitigate obsolescence issues, and improve reliability in support of Anti-Air Warfare (AAW) and Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) missions while still providing AN/SPY-1 Radar Total Ownership Cost (TOC) reductions. The improvements include, but are not limited to, installation for Sidewall Capacitor Circuit Protection and 10kW Traveling Wave Tube (TWT) Monitoring Circuits Ordnance Alterations (ORDALTS) for AN/SPY-1; B (V), D, D (V), CG and DDGs. Solid State Switch Assemblies (SSSA) will replace legacy switch tube modulator deck via an ORDALT.  Multi-Mission Signal Processor (MMSP) is the signal processor for the AN/SPY-1 radar.  MMSP Refresh (MMSP-R) cabinets will be procured to provide production representative configurations for land-based testing and training to support AEGIS ships at AEGIS Training and Readiness Center (ATRC) and Surface Combat System Center (SCSC) Wallops Island.  Procurement and installation of SSSA for DDG Ships, Shore Sites and Spares are aligned with the DDG Modernization availability periods.

Name.@footnote: Backend Equipment Sustainment funding is for performance based repair, replacement, and sparing of BEP hardware and management of obsolescence via attrition, required to achieve the systems readiness requirements.

Technology Baseline Modernization Funds configuration modernization every 7 years; incrementally refreshes COTS x86 BEP not already refreshed through attrition and non-COTS BEP required to maintain configuration baseline and align with industry standards and infrastructure.

Description.val:
DC024 AMDR Operations and Support (O&S) - AMDR has been designated the AN/SPY-6(V)1 to address Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) and Air Defense (AD) capability gaps identified in the Maritime Air and Missile Defense of Joint Forces (MAMDJF) Initial Capabilities Document (ICD); AN/SPY-6(V)1 will be initially fielded on the DDG-51 FLT-III platform. A variant of the AN/SPY-6(V) will replace the AN/SPY-1 radar on existing DDG 51 FLT-IIA ships. The AN/SPY-6(V) Product Support Strategy established NSWC Port Hueneme Division as the Product Support Integrator (PSI) for overall system Operational Availability (AO) and Backend Processing (BEP) subsystem(s) Life Cycle Support. The BEP is comprised of Commercial off the Shelf (COTS) x86 based Modular Open System Architecture (MOSA), allowing for Form-Fit-Function (FFF) replacement with next generation server and processer technology. A Product Support Provider (PSP), defined in the LCSP and Acquisition Strategy, as the Advanced Processing System (APS) contract vendor will execute Supply Support of the BEP. The APS PSP contributes to overall system readiness by managing BEP repair/replacement, obsolescence, and technology refresh by attrition within a performance based service contract, leveraging AN/SPY-6(V)'s MOSA and COTS x86 industrial base. Funding will sustain the Navy's next generation family of radars, AN/SPY-6(V). This applies to all current and future variants of the AN/SPY-6(V); including future modifications or separate programs to address different mission areas and utilization onboard different ship classes. 

The "To Complete" is represented of the AN/SPY-6(V)1's full 40 year life cycle across 22 ship years (880 ship years).

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: SPEIR BLOCK I
[none specified]:: Installation Name: SPEIR BLOCK I - SCALED
[none specified]:: Installation Name: NON-FMP SPEIR SHORE SITE

Description.val:
SPEIR Block I will provide a common EO/IR Electronic Support (ES) capability to all surface ships that will passively find, fix, track, and target current / emerging threats in support of the following warfare missions: Navigation, Counter Fast Attack Craft (FAC) / Fast In-shore Attack Craft (FIAC), Counter Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) / Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV), and Anti-Ship Cruise Missile (ASCM) Defense. SPEIR Block I will consist of a passive Wide Field of View (WFOV) capability with a 360 degree field-of-view optical sensor for panoramic detection, tracking, and identification for 24/7 day/night shipboard situational awareness.  SPEIR Block I will also include an enhanced, high resolution Narrow Field of View (NFOV)  and laser system capability that will provide range-finding and precision 3D target tracking. SPEIR Block II will be a future program that will build on Block I and add capability for Periscope Detection and Discrimination (PDD) and Mine Like Object (MLO) avoidance. Development Status/Major Milestones are: Milestone B, procurement of Long Lead Material (LLM) and Milestone C Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP).  The acquisition strategy for the FY23 LRIP units is to procure Long Lead Material (LLTM) for one shore site and one Fleet unit, with the completion of the FY23 LRIPs being awarded at MS C planned for 3QFY24.

There will be three configurations for the SPEIR Block I system:  1.1.1 SPEIR Block I provides funding for DDG 51, CG, LCS and LPD class ships and also consists of the WFOV, NFOV and laser capability.  1.1.2 SPEIR Block I Scaled is for CVN, LHD and LHA class ships.  The scaled configuration will provide the WFOV capability and will be integrated with existing NFOV capability on these classes of ships. 1.1.3 is the SPEIR Shore Site configuration. The shore site configuration is a partial configuration specifically to support shore based training and testing.
